headline.main: Lionel Aldridge, 56, Stalwart On Defense for Packer Teams

docs.abstract: Lionel Aldridge, defensive star on great Green Bay Packers teams of 1960's whose post-playing years were marked by mental illness, dies at age of 56; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Lionel Aldridge, a defensive star on the great Green Bay Packers teams of the 1960's whose post-playing years were marked by mental illness, was found dead by a daughter in his suburban Milwaukee apartment Thursday night. He was 56. The Milwaukee County Medical Examiner's office, which conducted an autopsy, said he weighed 408 1/2 pounds and had an enlarged heart, ''consistent with congestive heart failure and obesity.''

headline.main: Personal Health; Pass the Wine and Olive Oil, and Other Lessons From Crete

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on reputed health benefits of so-called Mediterranean diet, which relies far more on fruits and vegetables than diet recommended by Federal health officials in US; Mediterranean diet also includes considerable olive oil and moderate consumption of wine; in countries along Mediterranean, rates of heart disease and cancer are among lowest in world; many people think diet may explain good health of people who live there; 1960 study of 12,000 men in seven countries found that those least likely to develop heart disease lived on Island of Crete; near-vegetarian Cretan diet and active life style have undergone significant changes in last 30-odd years as islanders have become more affluent, shifting from farming to business, from cooperation toward competitiveness, achievement and materialism; drawings (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: OF 12,000 men in seven countries studied in 1960 by Dr. Ancel Keys, those least likely to develop heart disease lived on the Isle of Crete. His co-investigator, Dr. Henry Blackburn, professor emeritus at the University of Minnesota, has written that the low-risk Cretan ''is a shepherd or small farmer, a beekeeper or fisherman, or a tender of olives or vines,'' adding: ''He walks to work daily. His midday main meal is of eggplant with large mushrooms, crisp vegetables and country bread dipped in olive oil. Once a week there is a bit of lamb. Once a week there is chicken. Twice a week there is fish fresh from the sea. Other meals are hot dishes of legumes seasoned with meats and condiments. The main dish is followed by a tangy salad, then by dates, Turkish sweets, nuts or fresh fruits. A sharp local wine completes the meal.''
